item.title: As Trump Covets Nobel Peace Prize, FIFA Cozies Up to Him With Its Own Award
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, has been ingratiating himself with the president to help ensure a successful 2026 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, holding a replica of the men’s World Cup, with Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, in the Oval Office in August. Mr. Trump later asked to keep the trophy.

item.title: Second Strike Scrutiny Obscures Larger Question About Trump’s Boat Attacks
item.description: Congress is focusing on two deaths in one strike. But nine other people died in that same attack, and the United States has killed 87 in all. Were any of those killings legal?
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Adm. Frank M. Bradley attended a classified meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill.

item.title: Trump Trumpets Peace in Africa Amid War on Drug Boats, in Day of Dissonance
item.description: President Trump presided over a Congo-Rwanda peace deal on the same day his administration was being questioned about potential war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: President Trump trumpeted a peace agreement while hosting President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and President Felix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Switches Architects for White House Ballroom Project
item.description: The president had clashed with the original designer and insisted on increasing the size and scope of the ballroom on a short timeline.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:description: The demolition of the East Wing of the White House in October.

item.title: Trump Officials Cut Length of Work Permits for Asylum Seekers and Refugees
item.description: The move was the latest in an intensifying crackdown on legal immigration after an Afghan national was charged with shooting two National Guard members.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:description: A line outside a Los Angeles building housing U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services in June. Some migrants will now have to renew their work permits every 18 months instead of every five years.

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Way for Texas Redistricting Maps Pushed by Trump
item.description: Texas officials had asked the court to allow the state to use the new maps in the midterm elections, part of a push by President Trump to gain a partisan advantage.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.category: League of United Latin American Citizens
item.media:description: State Representative Matt Morgan, a Republican, holds a map of the new proposed congressional districts in Texas in August.

item.title: Grand Jury Said to Decline to Re-Indict Letitia James
item.description: After a judge dismissed the Trump administration’s first attempt to indict the attorney general of New York State, a new grand jury effort failed, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett and Jonah E. Bromwich
item.category: New York State Criminal Case Against Trump (71543-23)
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Letitia James, New York’s attorney general, has long been in President Trump’s crosshairs.

item.title: New Dietary Guidelines Delayed Until Early 2026
item.description: The updated Dietary Guidelines for Americans will not come until the new year, a government official said.
item.dc:creator: Alice Callahan
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, had said he would release the new guidelines in the summer, but they have been delayed.

item.title: Biden to Attend First Event for Presidential Library
item.description: His plans for the library have been slow to take shape, but he has invited potential donors to a holiday reception in Washington this month.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. appeared at a gala for the Nebraska Democratic Party last month in Omaha.

item.title: Appeals Court Pauses, for Now, Order Blocking National Guard in Washington
item.description: A week after the president surged more members of the National Guard to Washington, an appeals court halted an order that would have required the Guard to pull out after Dec. 11.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard on the National Mall in August.

item.title: Takeaways From the Pentagon Investigation on Hegseth’s Use of Signal
item.description: The inspector general concluded that the defense secretary violated the Pentagon’s instructions on using a private electronic device to share sensitive information.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth in Washington this week. He declined to be interviewed by the inspector general’s office.

item.title: Charles Norman Shay, Tribal Elder and World War II Hero, Dies at 101
item.description: As a medic, he saved soldiers from drowning off Omaha Beach on D-Day before becoming a prisoner of war. Back home, a decorated veteran, he was forbidden to vote as a Native American.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Charles Norman Shay at Omaha Beach in Normandy, France, in 2019. “I saw there were many wounded men who were floundering in the water,” he said, recalling D-Day. “And I knew that if nobody went to help them, they were doomed to die.”

item.title: As Health Care Subsidies Teeter, Congress Is Again at an Impasse
item.description: Democrats won an agreement for a floor showdown after the shutdown, but consensus still eludes the Senate. Will Republicans pay a political price?
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: With most Republicans opposed to the expiring Obamacare tax credits, the 60 votes needed to approve any extension do not exist in the Senate.

item.title: Bipartisan House Group Proposes Long-Shot Health Care Plan
item.description: Republicans and Democrats released a two-year plan to scale back and extend expiring Affordable Care Act subsidies, but it faces long odds in the G.O.P.-led House.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jen Kiggans is the leading Republican on the proposal to extend A.C.A. subsidies.

item.title: Boat Strike Video Shown to Lawmakers
item.description: Two survivors of the attack were said to struggle to cling to the boat before a second strike. After the briefing with lawmakers, the military disclosed a boat strike on Thursday that killed four people.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Megan Mineiro, Julian E. Barnes and Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Adm. Frank M. Bradley, left, and Gen. Dan Caine, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at the Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: Groups Express Anixety as Trump Threatens to Derail U.S.-Mexico-Canada Trade Pact
item.description: Hearings that began Wednesday in Washington reflected anxiety over the future of the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade pact and whether the president could end up scrapping it.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Though President Trump negotiated and signed the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement, he said this year that he wanted to make it a “much better deal.”

item.title: His Group Made World-Class Measurements of Atomic Elements
item.description: Yuri Ralchenko led one of the oldest teams at the National Institute for Standards and Technology. The fate of some experiments hangs in the air.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.category: National Institute of Standards and Technology
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times

item.title: Suspect Arrested in Inquiry Into Pipe Bombs in D.C. Ahead of Jan. 6 Riot
item.description: The suspect was described as a 30-year-old man from Prince William County, Va. His arrest could ultimately provide an answer to one of the mysteries arising from the Jan. 6. attack.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
item.media:description: A photograph released by the F.B.I. shows the person suspected of placing two pipe bombs on Capitol Hill the night before Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Poll Suggests Voters May Blame Republicans More if Affordable Care Act Subsidies Go Away
item.description: About half of people covered under the Affordable Care Act say that if their health costs spike, it will have a “major impact” on how they vote in the 2026 midterm elections, a survey found.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: If the Senate doesn’t vote to extend expanded Obamacare subsidies, many Americans will see their health expenses rise by about $1,000 next year.

item.title: Trump Says He ‘Ended’ the War Between Rwanda and Congo, but Fighting Persists
item.description: The president trumpeted a peace pact in a meeting with the two countries’ leaders that includes incentives for U.S. access to minerals. Fighting in eastern Congo has continued in the months since an earlier agreement.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Saikou Jammeh and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: The Trump administration held a signing ceremony for the peace agreement’s next phase at the U.S. Institute of Peace, which it recently renamed “the Donald J. Trump United States Institute of Peace.”

item.title: The Furor Over Trump’s Boat Attacks and a Particular Follow-Up Strike, Explained
item.description: Bipartisan congressional oversight is underway, but for now is focusing on narrow details about one missile instead of broader legal issues.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s orders regarding a lethal Sept. 2 attack on a boat in the Caribbean Sea are under scrutiny.

item.title: Inside RFK Jr.’s Methodical Quest to Shake Up America’s Vaccine System
item.description: The health secretary has walled himself off from government scientists and empowered fellow activists to pursue his vaccine agenda.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, conferring with Hannah Anderson, then one of his top advisers, during a hearing in May.
